128.11, the City Council revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for
one year and the licensee shall not be issued an adult oriented business
license for one year from the date revocation becomes effective. Said
revocation shall terminate any nonconforming use rights to use the property as
an adult oriented business.
128.11   HEARING, RULING AND APPEAL.
   1.   When the City Administrator issues a written notice of intent to deny,
suspend, or revoke a license, the City Administrator shall immediately send
such notice, which shall include the specific grounds under this chapter for
such action, to the applicant or licensee (respondent) by personal delivery or
certified mail. The notice shall be directed to the most current business
address or other mailing address on file with the City Administrator for the
respondent. The notice shall specify a date, not less than ten (10) days or
more than twenty (20) days after the date the notice is issued, on which the
City Administrator shall conduct a hearing on the City Administrator’s intent
to deny, suspend, or revoke the license.
   2.   At the hearing, the respondent shall have the opportunity to present
all of respondent’s arguments and to be represented by counsel, present
evidence and witnesses on his or her behalf, and cross-examine any of the City
Administrator’s witnesses. The City Administrator shall also be represented by
counsel, and shall bear the burden of proving the grounds for denying,
suspending, or revoking the license. The hearing shall take no longer than two
(2) days, unless extended at the request of the respondent to meet the
requirements of due process and proper administration of justice. The City
Administrator shall issue a written decision, including specific reasons for
the decision pursuant to this chapter, to the respondent within five (5) days
after the hearing. The decision of the City Administrator is final.
   3.   If the decision is to deny, suspend, or revoke the license, the
decision shall not become effective until the thirtieth (30th) day after it is
rendered, and the decision shall include a statement advising the respondent of
the right to appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction. If the
City Administrator’s decision finds that no grounds exist for denial,
suspension, or revocation of the license, the City Administrator shall,
contemporaneously with the issuance of the decision, immediately withdraw the
intent to deny, suspend, or revoke the license and to notify the respondent in
writing by certified mail of such action. If the respondent is not yet
licensed, the City Administrator shall contemporaneously therewith issue the
license to the applicant.
   4.   If any court action challenging the City Administrator’s decision is
initiated, the City Administrator shall prepare and transmit to the court a
transcript of the hearing within ten (10) days after receiving written notice
of the filing of the court action. The City Administrator shall consent to
expedited briefing and/or disposition of the action, shall comply with any
expedited schedule set by the court, and shall facilitate prompt judicial
review of the proceedings.
128.12   TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
A licensee shall not transfer his or her license to another, nor shall a
licensee operate an adult oriented business under the authority of a license at
any place other than the address designated in the adult oriented business
license application.
128.13   REGULATION OF EXHIBITION OF SEXUALLY EXPLICIT FILMS ON PREMISES.
   1.   A person who operates or causes to be operated a adult oriented
business, other than an adult motel, which exhibits on the premises in a
viewing room of less than 150 square feet of floor space, a film, video
cassette, or other video reproduction characterized by an emphasis on the
display of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas shall
comply with the following requirements:
      A.   Each application for an adult oriented business license shall
contain a diagram of the premises showing the location of all operator’s
stations, viewing rooms, overhead lighting fixtures, video cameras and monitors
installed for monitoring purposes and restrooms, and shall designate all
portions of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. Restrooms
shall not contain video reproduction equipment. The diagram shall also
designate the place at which the permit will be conspicuously posted, if
granted. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of an engineer’s or
architect’s blueprint shall not be required; however, each diagram shall be
oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and shall be drawn
to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various
internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy
of plus or minus six inches. The City Administrator may waive the foregoing
diagram for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was
previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of the premises has
not been altered since it was prepared.
      B.   It shall be the duty of the operator and of any employees present on
the premises to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the
premises which has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be
permitted in the application filed pursuant to paragraph 128.13(1)(A).
      C.   The interior premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting
fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are
permitted access at an illumination of not less than five (5.0) foot candles as
measured at the floor level. It shall be the duty of the operator, and of any
employees present on the premises, to ensure that the illumination described
above is maintained at all times that the premises is occupied by patrons or
open for business.
      D.   It shall be the duty of the operator and of any employees present on
the premises to ensure that no specified sexual activity occurs in or on the
licensed premises.
      E.   It shall be the duty of the operator to post conspicuous signs in
well-lighted entry areas of the business stating all of the following:
         (1)   The occupancy of viewing rooms is limited to one person.
         (2)   Sexual activity on the premises is prohibited.
         (3)   The making of openings between viewing rooms is prohibited.
         (4)   Violators will be required to leave the premises.
         (5)   Violations of subparagraphs (2), (3) and (4) of this paragraph
are unlawful.
      F.   It shall be the duty of the operator to enforce the regulations
articulated in Section
128.13(1)(E) above.
      G.   The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner
that there is an unobstructed view from a operator’s station of every area of
the premises, including the interior of each viewing room but excluding
restrooms, to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose. An
operator’s station shall not exceed 32 square feet of floor area. If the
premises has two (2) or more operator’s stations designated, then the interior
of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an
unobstructed view of each area of the premises to which any patron is permitted
access for any purpose from at least one of the operator’s stations. The view
required in this paragraph must be by direct line of sight from the operator’s
station. It is the duty of the operator to ensure that at least one employee is
on duty and situated in each operator’s station at all times that any patron is
on the premises. It shall be the duty of the operator, and it shall also be the
duty of any employees present on the premises, to ensure that the view area
specified in this paragraph remains unobstructed by any doors, curtains, walls,
merchandise, display racks or other materials or enclosures at all times that
any patron is present on the premises.
   2.   It is unlawful for a person having a duty under this section to
knowingly fail to fulfill that duty. Viewing rooms shall not contain a door or
curtains at the entrance to the room.
128.14   REGULATION OF ADULT CABARETS.
   1.   A person who operates or causes to be operated an adult cabaret shall
comply with the following requirements:
      A.   Each application for an adult oriented license to operate an adult
cabaret shall contain a diagram of the premises showing the location of the
bar, tables, booths, restrooms, private rooms, employee’s station, video
cameras and monitors installed for monitoring purposes and any private rooms on
the premises. The diagram shall also designate all portions of the premises
where patrons will not be permitted. Restrooms shall not contain video
reproduction equipment. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of and
engineer’s or architect’s blueprint shall not be required; however, each
diagram shall be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object
and shall be drawn to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient
to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the
premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The City Administrator may
waive the foregoing diagram for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a
diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of
the premises has not been altered since it was prepared.
      B.   It shall be the duty of the operator and of any employees present on
the premises to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the
premises which has been designated in the application filed pursuant to
subsection
128.14(1)(A) as an area in which patrons will not be permitted.
      C.   It is unlawful for an operator to permit a patron to be in a private
room unless an employee is available at the bar or an employee’s station that
provides unobstructed view of the private room.
      D.   It shall be the duty of the operator and of any employees present on
the premises to ensure that no specified sexual activity occurs in or on the
licensed premises.
      E.   It shall be the duty of the operator or the licensee to post
conspicuous signs in well-lighted entry areas of the business stating:
         (1)   Sexual activity on the premises is prohibited.
         (2)   Violators will be required to leave the premises.
         (3)   A violation of subparagraph (1) of this subsection is unlawful.
         (4)   Violators will be required to leave the premises.
      F.   It shall be the duty of the operator to enforce the regulations
articulated in Section
128.14(1)(E).
      G.   The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner
that there is an unobstructed view from bartender’s station or any manned
employee’s station of the premises including the interior of each private room
but excluding restrooms to which any patron is permitted access for any
purpose. An employee’s station shall not exceed 32 square feet of floor area.
If the premises has two or more employee stations designated, then the interior
of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an
unobstructed view of each area of the premises to which any patron is permitted
access for any purpose from at least one of the operator’s stations. The view
required in this paragraph must be by direct line of sight from the employee’s
station at all times that any patron is on the premises. It shall be the duty
of any employees present on the premises to ensure that the view area specified
in this paragraph remains unobstructed by any doors, curtains, walls,
merchandise, display racks or other materials or enclosures at all times that
any patron is present on the premises.
      H.   Private rooms shall not contain a door or curtains at the entrance
to the room. A “private room” for the purposes of this section is an area on
the licensed premises containing at least 64 square feet of floor space
enclosed by four walls intended to be used for dancing or any other conduct by
and between a patron and an employee.
   2.   It is unlawful for a person having a duty under this section to
knowingly fail to fulfill that duty.
128.15   LOITERING; EXTERIOR LIGHTING AND MONITORING REQUIREMENTS.
   1.   It shall be the duty of the operator of an adult oriented business to:
      A.   Post conspicuous signs stating that no loitering is permitted on
such property;
      B.   Designate one or more employees to monitor the activities of persons
on such property by visually inspecting such property at least once every
ninety (90) minutes or inspecting such property by use of video cameras and
monitors; and
      C.   Provide lighting of the exterior premises to provide for visual
inspection or video monitoring to prohibit loitering. If used, video cameras
and monitors shall operate continuously at all times that the premises are open
for business. The monitors shall be installed within an operator’s station.
   2.   It is unlawful for a person having a duty under this section to
knowingly fail to fulfill that duty.
   3.   No adult oriented business shall erect a fence, wall, or other barrier
that prevents any portion of the parking lot for the establishment from being
visible from a public right-of-way.
128.16   ENFORCEMENT.
The City’s legal counsel is hereby authorized to institute civil proceedings
necessary for the enforcement of this chapter to prosecute, restrain, or
correct violations hereof. Such proceedings, including injunction, shall be
brought in the name of the City, provided, however, that nothing in this
section and no action taken hereunder, shall be held to exclude such criminal
or administrative proceedings as may be authorized by other provisions of this
chapter, or any of the laws or ordinances in force in the City or to exempt
anyone violating this chapter or any part of the said laws from any penalty
which may be incurred.
128.17   PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
It is unlawful for an adult oriented business to knowingly violate the
following regulations or to knowingly allow an employee or any other person to
violate the following regulations.
   1.   It is a violation of this chapter for a patron, employee, or any other
person to knowingly or intentionally, in an adult oriented business, appear in
a state of nudity, regardless of whether such public nudity is expressive in
nature.
   2.   It is a violation of this chapter for a person to knowingly or
intentionally, in an adult oriented business, appear in a semi-nude condition
unless the person is an employee. It is a violation of this chapter for an
employee to touch any specified anatomical area of patron or for a patron to
touch any specified anatomical area of an employee or for an employee and a
patron to engage in any specified sexual activities on the adult oriented
business premises.
   3.   It is a violation of this chapter for any employee who regularly
appears semi-nude in an adult oriented business to knowingly or intentionally
touch a customer or the clothing of a customer on the premises of an adult
oriented business.
   A sign, in a form to be prescribed by the City Administrator’s office and
summarizing the provisions of this section, shall be posted near the entrance
of the adult oriented business in such a manner as to be clearly visible to
patrons upon entry.
128.18   SCIENTER REQUIRED TO PROVE VIOLATION OR BUSINESS LICENSEE LIABILITY.
This chapter does not impose strict liability. Unless a culpable mental state
is otherwise specified herein, a showing of a knowing or reckless mental state
is necessary to establish a violation of a provision of this chapter.
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, for the purposes of this chapter, an
act by an employee that constitutes grounds for suspension or revocation of
that employee’s license shall be imputed to the adult oriented business
licensee for purposes of finding a violation of this chapter, or for purposes
of license denial, suspension, or revocation, only if an officer, director, or
general partner, or a person who managed, supervised, or controlled the
operation of the business premises, knowingly or recklessly allowed such act to
occur on the premises. It shall be a defense to liability that the person to
whom liability is imputed was powerless to prevent the act.
128.19   FAILURE OF CITY TO MEET DEADLINE SHALL NOT RISK APPLICANT OR LICENSEE
RIGHTS.
In the event that a City official is required to take an act or do a thing
pursuant to this chapter within a prescribed time, and fails to take such act
or do such thing within the time prescribed, said failure shall not prevent the
exercise of constitutional rights of an applicant or licensee. If the act
required of the City official under this chapter, and not completed in the time
prescribed, includes approval of condition(s) necessary for approval by the
City of an applicant or licensee’s application for adult oriented business
license, the license shall be deemed granted and the business or employee
allowed to commence operations or employment the day after the deadline for the
City’s action has passed.
128.20   GENERAL REGULATIONS OF ALL ADULT ORIENTED BUSINESSES.
The following regulations shall apply to all classifications of adult oriented
businesses.
   1.   Location. No adult oriented business shall be located within the
following distances as measured by following a straight line, without regard to
intervening buildings, from the nearest point of the property parcel upon which
the proposed adult entertainment business is to be located, to the nearest
point of the parcel of property or district boundary line from which the
proposed adult entertainment business is to be separated.
      A.   Adult oriented businesses shall be prohibited within eight hundred
(800) feet of any dwelling (one-family, two-family or multiple dwelling) or
City Hall.
      B.   Adult oriented businesses shall be prohibited within eight hundred
(800) feet of any church, synagogue, mosque, temple, or other place of
religious worship.
      C.   Adult oriented businesses shall be prohibited within two thousand
(2,000) feet of any public or private school offering general education for
students between the years of Kindergarten and Twelfth grade, public library or
museum.
      D.   Adult oriented businesses shall be prohibited within two thousand
(2,000) feet of any registered daycare home or registered daycare business,
public park or playground.
      E.   Adult oriented businesses shall be prohibited within five hundred
(500) feet of any existing establishment selling alcoholic beverages for
consumption on premises.
   2.   Signage. The owner and operator of any adult oriented business shall
comply with Chapter 155 of the Sergeant Bluff Code of Ordinances applicable to
signage. Additionally, the display surfaces of the sign shall not contain
photographs, silhouettes, drawings, or pictorial representations of any
specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities.
   3.   Concealment and Protection. All building openings, entries, windows,
etc., of an adult oriented business shall be covered or screened in such a
manner as to prevent a view into the interior from any public or semi-public
area. Advertisements, displays or other promotional materials shall not be
shown or exhibited so as to be visible to the public from pedestrian sidewalks,
walkways or from other public or semi-public areas. Operator shall allow
inspection of the premises so as to determine compliance with this ordinance.
To protect the public safety, and the safety of all employees and patrons of an
adult oriented business, any person owns or operates an adult oriented business
must provide at least one law enforcement or trained professional security
person on the premises of each adult oriented business establishment during all
business hours.
   4.   Minors. It shall be unlawful to allow any person who is younger than
eighteen (18) years of age to enter or be on the premises of an adult oriented
business at any time that the establishment is open for business. The operator
must ensure that an attendant, such as any law enforcement or trained
professional security person, is stationed at each public entrance at all times
during regular business hours. The attendant shall prohibit any person under
the age of eighteen (18) from entering the establishment. It shall be presumed
that an attendant knew a person was under the age of eighteen (18) unless such
attendant asked for and was furnished a valid driver's license issued by a
state reflecting that person's age.
   5.   Alcohol. No alcohol shall be permitted in any adult oriented business,
unless such is specifically allowed pursuant to the Code of Iowa. This
prohibition applies equally to the operator and the patrons of the
establishment involved.
(Ord. 627 - Sep. 15 Supp.)
CHAPTER 129
MOTOR VEHICLE SALES
 
129.01 Purpose     129.03 Casual or Occasional Sales from Residential Property
                   Restricted
129.02 Definitions
 
129.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the casual and occasional sale of
motor vehicles on residential property so that such business transactions and
displays of motor vehicles do not create a nuisance, degrade surrounding
property values or interfere with other property owners’ enjoyment of their
property. The Council finds that regulation of casual and occasional sales of
motor vehicles from residential area is necessary to protect the public and
property within the City.
129.02   DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise,
the following terms are defined:
   1.   “At retail” means to dispose of a motor vehicle to a person who will
devote it to a consumer use.
   2.   “Casual and occasional sale” refers to the business of buying, selling,
transferring, or exchanging motor vehicles by any person who:
      A.   Intends to sell or transfer a motor vehicle at retail;
      B.   Displays the motor vehicle for sale or transfer to the public on
residential property;
      C.   Is not required to obtain a license to be a motor vehicle dealer
pursuant to Chapter 322 of the Code of Iowa; and
      D.   Does not have an established place of business other than the
person’s residence for such sale or transfer.
   3.   “Display” means to park a motor vehicle on the property and advertise
the same for sale by any means including signage, posters, or any other verbal
or written communication.
   4.   “Motor vehicle” means any vehicle, new or used, which is or may be
self-propelled, whether operational or not, and which is required to be
registered under the provisions of Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa.
   5.   “Residential property” means any lot used for residential occupancy,
including single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, multi-family
dwellings, group dwellings, or mobile homes.
   6.   “Sale” means the sale, exchange, or lease under any terms and
conditions, or any transfer of legal or equitable interest or ownership.
129.03   CASUAL OR OCCASIONAL SALES FROM RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY RESTRICTED.
The casual and occasional sale at retail or display for sale of any motor
vehicle by the owner thereof to the public from any residential property is
restricted as follows:
   1.   No more than three vehicles may be displayed on residential property
and sold, offered, or advertised for casual and occasional sale at retail from
the same residential property during a 12-month period.
   2.   Any motor vehicle displayed on residential property must be parked on a
driveway or other hard surface.
CHAPTER 130
SPECIAL EVENTS AND OUTDOOR ENTERTAINMENT
 
130.01 Special Events Permit Required  130.06 Glass Containers
130.02 Outdoor Entertainment Permit    130.07 Street Closings
Required
130.03 Commercial Vendors Permit       130.08 Miscellaneous Charges for Public
Required                               Services or Damages to Public Property
130.04 Authority of City Administrator 130.09 Appeal
130.05 Compliance with Applicable Laws
and Regulations
 
130.01   SPECIAL EVENTS PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person, organization, company, club, or other group may conduct any kind of
special event on City-owned property or facilities, including any City park,
street or sidewalk, without first obtaining a Special Events Permit from the
City Administrator. Special events include but are not limited to carnivals,
fairs, parades, races, fun runs/walks, festivals, and neighborhood block
parties. The following regulations apply to all special events in the City:
   1.   A Special Events Permit may be obtained through application to the City
Administrator. Information required shall include: the name of the event,
sponsor, where and when the event is to be held, a proposed map of the
location, information regarding contact person for the event and information
about the nature of the event. A permit for and/or license must be applied for
not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date of the entertainment or event.
   2.   A permit granted under this section shall not be transferable.
   3.   The City Administrator may require payment of a reasonable, non-
discriminatory fee for a permit to cover administrative expenses associated
with the regulation, oversight, coordination, and monitoring of the event.
   4.   Each permit holder conducting the special event in a public location or
on public property shall pay a refundable deposit of $250.00. The deposit shall
be returned upon verification by the City Administrator that the location
assigned to the special event is returned in a clean and undamaged condition
and that all of the special event property and materials used or generated as
part of the special event have been removed.
   5.   Any person or group conducting a special event on City property shall
work with the City Administrator to obtain approval for any necessary insurance
coverage for a special event either under the City’s policies and/or by
presenting sufficient certificates of insurance, naming the City as an insured
in a form and amount approved by the City Administrator.
   6.   The City Administrator may require the permit holder to provide any
necessary security, crowd control, trash receptacles or other clean up
services, and portable toilet facilities to accommodate the reasonably
anticipated crowd and activities for the special event.
   7.   If the City Administrator determines that any proposed special event
poses an unacceptable risk to public health, safety and welfare, it may deny
the issuance of a permit or may issue a permit conditioned upon compliance with
restrictions.
   8.   The City Administrator and the Chief of Police are authorized to
monitor all special events and take such action as may be necessary for the
protection of the public health, safety and welfare, including termination of
such event.
   9.   The conduct of any special event without obtaining a permit in
violation of the provisions of this chapter or conduct in violation of the
requirements of any permit shall be considered an emergency nuisance, as
defined by
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances. If this type of nuisance is determined
to exist by the City Administrator or the Chief of Police, an emergency
abatement procedure pursuant to Section
50.06 of this Code of Ordinances is hereby authorized and may be executed by
any peace officers or those acting at their direction. The special event shall
be terminated and any property, material, or equipment impounded, without
notice, in accordance with Section 364.12(3)(a) and (h) of the Code of Iowa in
the event the organizer in violation fails to remove any property, material, or
equipment after being cited for a violation of this chapter. Emergency
abatement under this section shall not prohibit the imposition of additional
penalties provided for violations of this chapter.
130.02   OUTDOOR ENTERTAINMENT PERMIT REQUIRED.
No outdoor entertainment shall be held or conducted in the City without first
obtaining an Outdoor Entertainment Permit from the City Administrator. The
following regulations shall apply to all outdoor entertaining in the City:
   1.   An Outdoor Entertainment Permit may be obtained through application to
the City Administrator. A special/extended liquor license may be obtained
through application to the City Council. A permit and/or license must be
applied for not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date of the
entertainment or event.
   2.   A permit and/or license shall not be transferable.
   3.   The City Administrator and/or City Council may require payment of a
reasonable, non-discriminatory fee for a permit to cover administrative
expenses associated with the regulation, oversight, coordination and monitoring
of the event.
   4.   Decibel levels of outdoor entertainment shall be reasonable under the
circumstances, time and location, and shall be subject to the control of the
City Administrator and the Chief of Police of the City.
   5.   Outdoor sales of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted only in full
compliance with the Code of Iowa and the ordinances of the City; however, in no
event will special/extended outdoor liquor licenses provide for outdoor sales
beyond 2:00 a.m.
   6.   Outdoor entertainment permits and special/extended outdoor liquor
licenses shall only be granted upon certification of compliance with all
requirements of State and local law, the submission of acceptable premises and
event liability insurance, licensee’s providing acceptable security and age
verification procedures, including but not limited to providing for uniformed
off duty law enforcement or other acceptable security at the site, and
licensee’s providing portable toilet facilities to accommodate patrons.
   7.   If the City Administrator determines that any proposed outdoor
entertaining event poses an unacceptable risk to public health, safety and
welfare, it may deny the issuance of a permit or may issue a permit conditioned
upon compliance with restrictions.
   8.   The City Administrator and the Chief of Police are authorized to
monitor all outdoor entertaining events and take such action as may be
necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare,
including termination of such event.
   9.   The conduct of any outdoor entertaining event without obtaining an
Outdoor Entertainment Permit or special/extended outdoor liquor licenses in
violation of the provisions of this chapter or conduct in violation of the
requirements of any permit shall be considered an emergency nuisance, as
defined by
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances. If this type of nuisance is determined
to exist by the City Administrator or the Chief of Police, an emergency
abatement procedure pursuant to Section
50.06 of this Code or Ordinances is hereby authorized and may be executed by
any peace officers or those acting at their direction. The outdoor entertaining
event shall be terminated and any property, material, or equipment impounded,
without notice, in accordance with Section 364.12(3)(a) and (h) of the Code of
Iowa in the event the organizer in violation fails to remove any property,
material, or equipment after being cited for a violation of this chapter.
Emergency abatement under this section shall not prohibit the imposition of
additional penalties provided for violations of this chapter.
130.03   COMMERCIAL VENDORS PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person club, group, organization, corporation or entity of any kind shall
operate a booth or other temporary place of business to provide or sell goods,
merchandise, food or beverages to the public in conjunction with any special
event or outdoor entertainment in the City without first applying for and
obtaining a Commercial Vendors Permit from the City Administrator. However, any
person or entity that is a resident of Woodbury County and in possession of a
valid permit issued by the State of Iowa for the sale of food to be consumed on
its premises no less than one month prior to any event, or in possession of a
current Iowa retail sales tax permit, shall be exempt from the requirements of
this section. These requirements apply only to vendors seeking to operate at a
location other than their regularly established place of business. Businesses
in the City which operate only from their regularly established locations are
exempt from the requirements of this section. The following regulations shall
apply to all commercial vendors subject to this chapter:
   1.   A Commercial Vendors Permit may be obtained through application to the
City Administrator. A permit must be applied for not less than seven (7) days
prior to the date of the event or entertainment.
   2.   A permit granted under this section shall not be transferable.
   3.   The City Administrator may require payment of a reasonable, non-
discriminatory fee for a permit to be charged to all food and non-food vendors.
The purpose of the fee will be to cover administrative expenses associated with
the regulation, oversight, coordination, and monitoring of the event. Vendors
may also pay an optional electrical hookup fee for a location with electrical
access.
   4.   Each vendor planning to operate in a public location on public property
shall pay a refundable deposit of $50.00. The deposit shall be returned upon
verification by the City Administrator that the location assigned to the vendor
is returned in a clean and undamaged condition and that all of the vendor’s
property and materials used or generated in the operation of the booth have
been removed.
   5.   A vendor who has been granted a Commercial Vendor Permit shall locate
its temporary sale facility at a location to be approved by the City
Administrator.
   6.   A vendor who has been granted a Commercial Vendor Permit shall be
permitted to conduct business only in compliance with the rules and regulations
established by the City Administrator and upon payment of the fees and charges
required.
   7.   All persons or entities issued a Commercial Vendor Permit pursuant to
this chapter shall comply with the Iowa Department of Health and Woodbury
County Department of Health rules and regulations pertaining to the sale and
dispensing of food for consumption on its premises.
   8.   If the City Administrator determines that any proposed vendor booth
poses an unacceptable risk to public health, safety and welfare, it may deny
the issuance of a permit or may issue a permit conditioned upon compliance with
restrictions.
   9.   The City Administrator is authorized to monitor all vendor booths
during the event or festivities, and take such action as may be necessary for
the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare, including termination
of operations and sales at any booth.
   10.   The sale of food or other merchandise or the erection of a temporary
facility for the sale of food or other merchandise without obtaining a
Commercial Vendor Permit or conduct in violation of the provisions of this
chapter shall be considered an emergency nuisance, as defined by
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances. If this type of nuisance is determined
to exist, an emergency abatement procedure pursuant to Section
50.06 of this Code of Ordinances is hereby authorized and may be executed by
any peace officers or those acting at their direction. The nuisance shall be
dismantled and removed and any merchandise, property, material, or equipment
impounded, without notice, in accordance with Section 364.12(3)(a) and (h) of
the Code of Iowa in the event said violator fails to remove any merchandise,
property, material, or equipment after being cited for a violation of this
chapter. Emergency abatement under this section shall not prohibit the
imposition of additional penalties provided for violations of this chapter.
However, if the only nuisance or violation of this chapter is the offender’s
failure to obtain the necessary permit, the City Administrator, in lieu of
immediate abatement, may allow the person or entity to immediately fulfill the
requirements of this chapter to obtain and purchase a necessary permit as
provided by this chapter, subject to an additional late application fee.
130.04   AUTHORITY OF CITY ADMINISTRATOR.
The City Administrator is hereby granted the right and authority to review
permit applications, approve such applications, impose conditions for issuance
of any permit, and supervise, administer, and control the actions of permit
holders. Authority granted shall include:
   1.   Designation and regulation of locations for special events, including
appropriate parking areas, outdoor entertainment and vendor sites.
   2.   Collection of reasonable non-discriminatory user fees to offset
permitting, coordination, administration and regulation costs and expenses.
   3.   Denial of access or use of the sites, as may be necessary, for the
protection of the public health, safety and welfare.
   4.   Obtaining and receiving the aid of the Sergeant Bluff Police Department
in exercising the rights and authority granted under this chapter.
   5.   Waiver of specific requirements as may be appropriate, including waiver
of deposit and permitting fees for local, neighborhood, nonprofit, charitable,
educational or civic agencies and organizations, as well as for governmental or
primarily tax supported agencies.
130.05   COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS.
All activities for special events and outdoor entertainment shall comply with
all City ordinances not suspended by this chapter and all applicable State laws
and regulations, including but not limited to the requirements of
Chapter 122 addressing peddlers, solicitors, and transient merchants,
regulations of the Iowa Department of Health, Iowa Department of Revenue, and
the Iowa Alcoholic Beverage Division.
130.06   GLASS CONTAINERS.
To promote safety during any special events, all beverages sold by a commercial
booth permit holder from any outdoor location, shall be sold in non-glass
containers only. This requirement shall also apply to outdoor entertaining
events and any existing business, restaurant, service station, grocery store or
other establishment selling beverages on its premises in an outdoor setting
open to the public.
130.07   STREET CLOSINGS.
Any request for street or sidewalk closing as part of a special event or
outdoor entertainment activity shall be requested as part of the permit
application process and approved by the City Administrator. Any blocking of any
streets or sidewalks must be authorized by the City Administrator or any peace
officer. With or without prior City Council approval regarding the blocking of
any City streets or sidewalks, any peace officers or those at their direction
may place barricades or road blocks in any City street, alley, or roadway to
redirect vehicular traffic in order to enhance the proper and safe flow of
pedestrian, bicycle, and vehicular traffic within the City limits.
130.08   MISCELLANEOUS CHARGES FOR PUBLIC SERVICES OR DAMAGES TO PUBLIC
PROPERTY.
The City reserves the right to charge permit holders for extraordinary expenses
incurred by the City or any damages to public property as a result of the
special event or conduct of the permit holder.
130.09   APPEAL.
Any person aggrieved by a decision of or requirement imposed by the City
Administrator under this chapter may appeal such decision or requirement to the
City Council under the following procedure:
   1.   All appeals shall be in writing, shall include the name and address of
the appellant. shall describe the decision or requirement appealed from, and
shall state the relief requested.
   2.   Appeals under this section shall be submitted to the office of the City
Clerk at City Hall, within thirty (30) days of any action from which appeal is
taken or no less than ten (10) days prior to any festival or event.
   3.   All complete and timely filed appeals shall be considered by the City
Council at its regular meeting, or a special meeting if necessary, which shall
be held in City Hall.
   4.   Upon consideration of an appeal, the City Council shall issue a final
decision and may uphold the decision or requirement or may revise or reverse
such decision or requirement and may grant all or a portion of the relief
sought.
   5.   Any person or entity aggrieved by any decision of the City Council may
within thirty (30) days from date of final decision by the City Council, appeal
therefrom to the District Court for Woodbury County.
CHAPTER 131
TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND MOBILE FOOD UNITS
131.01 Purpose                   131.11 Location Authorization and Insurance
131.02 Definitions               131.12 License Not Transferable
131.03 License Required          131.13 Revocation of License
131.04 Application for License   131.14 Notice of Revocation or Denial
131.05 License Fees and Duration 131.15 Effect of Revocation
131.06 No Bond Required          131.16 Appeal
131.07 License Issued            131.17 License Exemptions
131.08 Display of License        131.18 Charitable and Nonprofit Organizations
131.09 Time Restriction          131.19 Standards for Mobile Food Vendors
131.10 Additional Approvals
 
131.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
residents of the City by means of licensing and regulating transient merchant,
mobile food unit and push cart sales.
131.02   DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
   1.   "Transient Merchant" means any person who engages in a temporary or
itinerant merchandising business offering goods or services and who in the
course of such business hires, leases or occupies any building or structure
whatsoever, or who operates out of a vehicle which is parked anywhere within
the City limits. The definition shall also include those who take or attempt to
take orders for the sale of goods, subscriptions, advertising or services to be
performed in the future. Temporary association with a local merchant, dealer,
trader or auctioneer, or conduct of such transient business in connection with,
as a part of, or in the name of any local merchant, dealer, trader or
auctioneer does not exempt any person from being considered a transient
merchant.
   2.   "Mobile Food Unit" means any readily movable vehicle (on wheels), that
is self-propelled (driven), or can be pulled or pushed to a location and used
for the vending of food or beverage items to the public.
   3.   "Push Cart" means any non-self-propelled movable unit that is pushed or
pulled by a vendor and serving a limited offering of food or beverage items.
131.03   LICENSE REQUIRED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a transient
merchant, mobile food unit or push cart without first obtaining a license as
herein provided. Any person engaging in sales in the City without first
obtaining a license as herein provided is in violation of this chapter and is
guilty of a simple misdemeanor.
131.04   APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
A verified application in writing on a form to be furnished by the City shall
be filed with the Code Enforcement Officer for a license under this chapter. No
license shall be issued unless the applicant for a license files an application
containing the following information:
   1.   The applicant's name, driver's license or government issued
identification number, permanent and local addresses and phone numbers and
business address and phone number, if any.
   2.   The applicant's employer, if any, and the employer's address and phone
number, including the name or names of the person or person having the
management or supervision of the applicant's business.
   3.   A brief description of the nature of the applicant's or employer's
business and the goods, food, beverages or services to be sold including as
applicable:
      A.   A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal
property or service to be sold or offered for sale; whether the goods are new,
damaged or rejects; whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in
possession or by sample, or by direct sale or by having orders for future
delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or
produced and where such goods or products are located at the time said
application is filed;
      B.   A statement of the nature and character of the food and beverages to
be sold or offered for sale;
      C.   A statement as to whether the business will be operated on public
property.
   4.   The names and locations of the last three municipalities where the
applicant carried on business within the past two (2) years if any.
   5.   The length of time sought to be covered by the license to include the
date(s) upon which it is the intention of the applicant to engage in the
proposed business operations.
   6.   A recent photograph or copy of driver's license or government issued ID
including photograph of the applicant.
   7.   A description of any motor vehicles to be used in conjunction with the
applicant's operation including make, model, year, color and their respective
license plate numbers.
   8.   A description of any push cart to be used in conjunction with the
applicant's operation and sales.
   9.   Written permission to sell from the location, by lease or otherwise, of
the owner or person in control of the property which shall include the dates
the transient merchant, mobile food vendor or push cart operator shall be
conducting business.
   10.   A statement as to whether the applicant has ever applied and been
denied a license under this chapter and a statement as to whether the applicant
has ever had a license under this chapter which has been revoked.
   11.   A statement as to the number of months requested for the license.
   12.   If the applicant is selling food or beverages from a vehicle, trailer,
push cart or food stand, a copy of a current and valid mobile food unit license
issued by the Siouxland District Health Department is required.
   13.   Any other pertinent information requested by the Code Enforcement
Officer.
   14.   Payment of the license fees that would apply for the applicable
license period if approved.
131.05   LICENSE FEES AND DURATION.
   1.   Licenses shall be issued for a specific time period, in monthly
increments up to a maximum of 6 months, and the beginning and ending dates
shall be specified.
   2.   The license fee shall be $15.00 per month as follows:
      One Month:       $15.00
      Two Months:    $30.00
      Three Months:    $45.00
      Four Months:    $60.00
      Five Months:    $75.00
      Six Months:       $90.00
   3.   All fees shall be paid to the Clerk with the application and prior to
the issuance of any license. If any license is not approved after review, funds
paid with the application will be refunded, less a $15.00 charge to cover the
cost for review, investigation and any necessary communications regarding the
license application.
131.06   NO BOND REQUIRED.
No separate bond is required by the City.
131.07   LICENSE ISSUED.
Upon receiving an application, the Code Enforcement Officer shall review the
application and complete any additional investigation necessary which may
include a personal interview of the applicant. Consideration may be given to
reports from other communities, complaints from the public and past problems,
including actions resulting in denial or revocation of a license under this
chapter. If the Code Enforcement Officer finds that the applicant is of good
reputation and character, the application is completed in conformance with the
requirements of this chapter, the facts stated therein are found to be correct
and the license fees are paid, a license shall be issued. A waiting period of
three to seven business days may be applicable to allow sufficient time for
application review.
131.08   DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
Each license holder shall keep such license in possession at all times while
doing business in the City and shall, upon the request of prospective customers
or any peace officer, exhibit the license as evidence of compliance with all
requirements of this chapter. Any license holder who fails to display a valid
license shall be in violation of this chapter and is guilty of a simple
misdemeanor.
131.09   TIME RESTRICTION.
All licenses shall provide that said licenses are in force and effect one hour
after sunrise until sunset, Monday through Sunday. Food vendors may operate for
extended hours by providing to the Code Enforcement Officer written
authorizations for specific hours provided by the property owner or person in
control of the property from which the food vendor will operate. Any transient
merchant who operates outside of such times shall be in violation of this
chapter and is guilty of a simple misdemeanor.
131.10   ADDITIONAL APPROVALS.
Receiving a license under this chapter from the City shall not preclude,
supersede, circumvent, or waive the applicant's responsibility to obtain any
additional permits, licenses, and approvals for other applicable local or state
regulations.
131.11   LOCATION AUTHORIZATION AND INSURANCE.
A mobile food unit or push cart may be parked on public property or street if
approved and authorized in the license issued, subject to the license holder
providing a current valid Certificate of Liability Insurance to the City Clerk
for all time periods in operation under the license issued.
131.12   LICENSE NOT TRANSFERABLE.
Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter are not transferable under
any circumstances and are to be applicable only to the person filing the
application.
131.13   REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
The Code Enforcement Officer may revoke or temporarily suspend any license
issued under the provisions of this chapter for any of the following reasons:
   1.   For any violations of this chapter or any other City ordinance or State
law.
   2.   For making false or misleading statements or representations on the
application form or as part of the application process.
   3.   For making false or misleading statements or misrepresentations
regarding the sales of goods, services, subscriptions or merchandise.
   4.   For complaints of using aggressive sales tactics.
   5.   For circumstances that present a danger to the health, physical safety
or financial well-being of the public, customers, or potential customers.
131.14   NOTICE OF REVOCATION OR DENIAL.
The Code Enforcement Officer may revoke or deny any license by personal service
or by certified mail to the license holder or applicant at the address(es)
shown on the application.
131.15   EFFECT OF REVOCATION.
Revocation of any license shall bar the licensee from being eligible for any
license under this chapter for a period of one year from the date of the
revocation.
131.16   APPEAL.
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Code Enforcement Officer under this
chapter may appeal such decision to the City Council under the following
procedure:
   1.   All appeals shall be in writing, shall include the name and address of
the applicant or licensee, shall describe the decision being appealed and shall
state the relief requested.
   2.   Appeals under this section shall be filed with the City Clerk at City
Hall within ten business days of any action from which appeal is taken.
   3.   All complete and timely filed appeals shall be considered by the City
Council at its next regular meeting scheduled for no less than ten business
days following receipt of the appeal. Notice of the consideration of the appeal
including an opportunity to be heard shall be given to the appellant by
certified mail to the address filed on the appeal.
   4.   The City Council shall conduct a public hearing allowing the Code
Enforcement Officer and the appellant to present evidence and testify regarding
the allegations relevant to the appeal. Should the appellant or an authorized
representative fail to appear without good cause, the City Council may proceed
to a determination of the complaint in such absence.
   5.   The City Council shall issue a final decision and may uphold, reverse
or revise the decision of the Code Enforcement Officer and may grant none, all
or a portion of the relief sought. The City Council shall make and record
findings of fact and conclusions of law, and shall revoke a license only when
upon review of the entire record the City Council finds by majority vote clear
and convincing evidence of grounds to grant, deny or revoke such license.
   6.   Any person or entity aggrieved by any decision of the City Council may
within thirty days from the date of final decision by the City Council, appeal
therefrom to the District Court of Woodbury County.
131.17   LICENSE EXEMPTIONS.
The following are excluded from the application of this chapter and do not need
to apply for and obtain a license:
   1.   Newspapers. Persons delivering, collecting for or selling subscriptions
to newspapers.
   2.   Club Members. Members of local civic and service clubs, scout troops 4-
H Clubs, Future Farmers of America and similar organizations.
   3.   Students. Students representing the Sergeant Bluff/Luton School
District conducting projects sponsored by organizations recognized by the
school.
   4.   Route Sales. Route delivery persons who only incidentally solicit
additional business or make special sales.
   5.   Resale or Institutional Use. Persons customarily calling on businesses
or institutions for the purposes of selling products for resale or
institutional use.
   6.   Sales of Certain Items. Individuals selling or distributing livestock
feeds, fresh meats, fish, fruit, or vegetables.
   7.   Sales of Labor Services. Individuals selling their own work or
production.
   8.   Arts and Crafts. Persons who sell at their permanent residence in the
city works of art or crafts made or created by such person or a member of such
person's immediate family.
   9.   Mobile Food Units not Open for Sale to the Public. Mobile food units
contracted to provide food for a catered event in which the food is not served
directly from the mobile food unit or in which the contracting party is paying
for all food provided rather than individual patrons paying for their food.
   10.   Commercial Vendors Permit Holders. Vendors who obtain a Commercial
Vendors Permit pursuant to Section 130.03 in connection with a special event or
outdoor entertainment authorized by the City under Chapter 130.
   11.   Stands Operated by Minors. Minors who operate a stand to sell or
otherwise distribute food or beverages, such as lemonade stand. Except that
while stands operated by minors do not require a license, any stands must be
operated in a safe manner, located on private property, and may not be set up
in the public right-of-way.
131.18   CHARITABLE AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.
Authorized representatives of charitable or nonprofit organizations operating
under the provisions of Chapter 504 of the Code of Iowa desiring to solicit
money or to distribute literature are exempt from the operation of Sections
131.04, 131.04, 131.05 and 131.06. All such organizations are required to
submit in writing to the Code Enforcement Officer the name and purpose of the
cause for which such activities are sought, names and addresses of the officers
and directors of the organization, the period during which such activities are
to be carried on, and whether any commissions, fees or wages are to be charged
by the solicitor and the amount thereof. If the Code Enforcement Officer finds
that the organization is a bona fide charity or nonprofit organization the Code
Enforcement Officer shall issue, free of charge, a license containing the above
information to the applicant. In the event the Code Enforcement Officer denies
the exemption, the authorized representatives of the organization may appeal
the decision to the Council, as provided in Section 131.14 of this chapter.
131.19   OPERATING STANDARDS FOR MOBILE FOOD VENDORS.
Mobile food unit vendors must adhere to the following regulations:
   1.   Mobile food units shall only serve patrons who are on foot; no drive-up
service to the mobile food unit shall be provided or allowed.
   2.   All mobile food units shall maintain a minimum separation from
buildings of ten (10) feet as measured to the closest building element
including awnings or canopies, tents, or membrane structures. Location of the
mobile food unit shall not impede pedestrians entering or exiting a building.
   3.   The window or area where a patron orders and receives their purchase
shall be located so as not to require a patron to stand, or create a line, that
may cause pedestrians to be in the public right-of-way, vehicle travel lane,
including parking lot drive aisles, or similar situation that may create a
potential safety hazard. Adequate space for patrons waiting for their order
must be available or blocked off on the property where the mobile food unit is
located.
   4.   Signs are limited to those that are attached to the exterior of the
mobile unit and must be mounted flat against the unit and not project more than
six (6) inches from the exterior of the unit. In addition, each mobile unit may
have up to two (2) freestanding signs, banners, flags, or similar items if such
item is placed within ten (10) feet of the mobile unit and so long as such item
(s) does not interfere with traffic or create a safety hazard. Off premises
signs directing patrons to the mobile unit are prohibited.
   5.   During business hours, the mobile food vendor shall provide a trash
receptacle for use by customers and shall keep the area around the mobile food
unit clear of litter and debris at all times.
   6.   All mobile food units shall be located in such a manner as to not
create a safety hazard, such as blocking emergency access to buildings and the
site, obstructing access to fire hydrants, impeding entering and exiting from a
building, creating a visual impediment for the motoring public at drive
entrances, intersections, pedestrian crossings, or similar movement and access.
(Ch. 131 - Ord. 735 - May 23 Supp.)
CHAPTER 135
STREET USE AND MAINTENANCE
 
135.01 Removal of Warning Devices        135.08 Burning Prohibited
135.02 Obstructing or Defacing           135.09 Excavations
135.03 Placing Debris On                 135.10 Maintenance and Restrictions on
                                         Use of Parking or City Right-Of-Way
135.04 Playing In                        135.11 Failure to Maintain Parking or
                                         Terrace
135.05 Traveling on Barricaded Street or 135.12 Dumping of Snow
Alley
135.06 Use for Business Purposes         135.13 Driveway Culverts
135.07 Washing Vehicles                  135.14 Curb Construction Permits
 
135.01   REMOVAL OF WARNING DEVICES.
It is unlawful for a person to willfully remove, throw down, destroy or carry
away from any street or alley any lamp, obstruction, guard or other article or
things, or extinguish any lamp or other light, erected or placed thereupon for
the purpose of guarding or enclosing unsafe or dangerous places in said street
or alley without the consent of the person in control thereof.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
135.02   OBSTRUCTING OR DEFACING.
It is unlawful for any person to obstruct, deface or injure any street or alley
in any manner.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
135.03   PLACING DEBRIS ON.
It is unlawful for any person to throw or deposit on any street or alley any
glass, glass bottle, nails, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter,
offal, leaves, grass or any other debris likely to be washed into the storm
sewer and clog the storm sewer, or any substance likely to injure any person,
animal or vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.369)
135.04   PLAYING IN.
It is unlawful for any person to coast, sled, or play games on streets or
alleys, except in the areas blocked off by the City for such purposes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2])
135.05   TRAVELING ON BARRICADED STREET OR ALLEY.
It is unlawful for any person to travel or operate any vehicle on any street or
alley temporarily closed by barricades, lights, signs, or flares placed thereon
by the authority or permission of any City official, police officer or member
of the Fire Department.
135.06   USE FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES.
It is unlawful to park, store or place, temporarily or permanently, any
machinery or junk or any other goods, wares, and merchandise of any kind upon
any street or alley for the purpose of storage, exhibition, sale or offering
same for sale, without permission of the Council.
135.07   WASHING VEHICLES.
It is unlawful for any person to use any public sidewalk, street, or alley for
the purpose of washing or cleaning any automobile, truck equipment, or any
vehicle of any kind when such work is done for hire or as a business. This does
not prevent any person from washing or cleaning his or her own vehicle or
equipment when it is lawfully parked in the street or alley.
135.08   BURNING PROHIBITED.
No person shall burn any trash, leaves, rubbish, or other combustible material
in any curb and gutter or on any paved or surfaced street or alley.
135.09   EXCAVATIONS.
No person shall dig, excavate, or in any manner disturb any street, parking or
alley except in accordance with the following:
   1.   Permit Required. No excavation shall be commenced without first
obtaining a permit therefor. A written application for such permit shall be
filed with the City and shall contain the following:
      A.   An exact description of the property, by lot and street number, in
front of or along which it is desired to excavate;
      B.   A statement of the purpose, for whom and by whom the excavation is
to be made;
      C.   The person responsible for the refilling of said excavation and
restoration of the street or alley surface; and
      D.   Date of commencement of the work and estimated completion date.
   2.   Public Convenience. Streets and alleys shall be opened in the manner
which will cause the least inconvenience to the public and admit the
uninterrupted passage of water along the gutter on the street.
   3.   Barricades, Fencing and Lighting. Adequate barricades, fencing and
warning lights meeting standards specified by the City shall be so placed as to
protect the public from hazard. Any costs incurred by the City in providing or
maintaining adequate barricades, fencing or warning lights shall be paid to the
City by the permit holder/property owner.
   4.   Restoration of Public Property. Streets, sidewalks, alleys and other
public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored to the
condition of the property prior to the commencement of the work, or in a manner
satisfactory to the City, at the expense of the permit holder/property owner.
   5.   Inspection. All work shall be subject to inspection by the City.
Backfill shall not be deemed completed, and no resurfacing of any improved
street or alley surface shall begin, until such backfill is inspected and
approved by the City. The permit holder/property owner shall provide the City
with notice at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time when inspection
of backfill is desired.
   6.   Completion by the City. Should any excavation in any street or alley be
discontinued or left open and unfinished for a period of twenty-four (24) hours
after the approved completion date, or in the event the work is improperly
done, the City has the right to finish or correct the excavation work and
charge any expenses therefor to the permit holder/property owner.
   7.   Responsibility for Costs. All costs and expenses incident to the
excavation shall be borne by the permit holder and/or property owner. The
permit holder and owner shall indemnify the City from any loss or damage that
may directly or indirectly be occasioned by such excavation.
   8.   Notification. At least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the commencement
of the excavation, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, the person
performing the excavation shall contact the Statewide Notification Center and
provide the center with the information required under Section 480.4 of the
Code of Iowa.
   9.   Permit Issued. Upon approval of the application, a permit shall be
issued. A separate permit shall be required for each excavation.
135.10   MAINTENANCE AND RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF PARKING OR CITY RIGHT-OF-WAY..
It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner to maintain all
property outside the lot and property lines and inside the curb lines upon the
public streets, (hereafter called the parking), except that the abutting
property owner shall not be required to remove diseased trees or dead wood on
such property. Maintenance includes timely mowing of grass, weed control,
trimming, pruning trees and shrubs, picking up litter and keeping the parkway
free of obstructions or depressions which might be injurious to the general
public. In addition, the abutting property owner shall not plant any trees,
park any vehicle, or place any fencing, barrier, planting or other material of
any kind except the planting of grass seed and maintenance of grass lawn on the
parking. The abutting property owner shall not place any concrete, gravel,
asphalt, surface material or piping whatsoever in the parking. The only
exceptions to the prohibitions of this section shall be limited to the
following:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2c])
   1.   An abutting property owner on the streets located within the boundaries
of First and Eighth Streets and B Street to Front Street may park a vehicle on
the parking, but the parking area so used must be constructed of either asphalt
or concrete pavement and be in compliance with Sections 165C.13 through 165C.18
of the Zoning Regulations.
(Ord. 747 - Apr. 24 Supp.)
   2.   Postal boxes may be installed and maintained in the parking area as
specified by the U.S. Post Office; and
   3.   Sprinkler heads and associated lines may be installed in compliance
with Chapter 160 regarding underground lawn-sprinkling systems.
Any sprinkler, structure, planting or other installation in the parking area
which would be in violation of this section that is in place as of January 1,
2012 will be allowed to remain in its present condition. No additional
plantings, structures or other installations may be added which are not in
compliance with this section. In the event that the City or any other
authorized user of the right-of-way completes maintenance or excavation of any
parking area not in compliance with this section, the parking area must be
restored in compliance with this section and may not be restored to the pre-
existing non-compliant condition. Abutting property owners of parking areas
which are not in compliance with this section will bear all costs for loss or
damage to plantings, structures or other installations in the parking which are
not in compliance with this section. The City and other authorized users of the
right-of-way will only be required to restore the parking to any pre-existing
condition in compliance with this section. The City and other authorized users
of the right-of-way shall not be liable for removal, re-installation or damage
of any sprinkler, structure, planting or other installation in the parking
area.
(Ord. 656 – Aug. 17 Supp.)
135.11   FAILURE TO MAINTAIN PARKING OR TERRACE.
If the abutting property owner does not perform an action required under the
above section within a reasonable time, the City may perform the required
action and assess the cost against the abutting property for collection in the
same manner as a property tax.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2e])
135.12   DUMPING OF SNOW.
It is unlawful for any person to throw, push, or place or cause to be thrown,
pushed or placed, any ice or snow from private property, sidewalks, or
driveways onto the traveled way of a street or alley so as to obstruct gutters,
or impede the passage of vehicles upon the street or alley or to create a
hazardous condition therein; except where, in the cleaning of large commercial
drives in the business district it is absolutely necessary to move the snow
onto the street or alley temporarily, such accumulation shall be removed
promptly by the property owner or agent. Arrangements for the prompt removal of
such accumulations shall be made prior to moving the snow.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[2])
135.13   DRIVEWAY CULVERTS.
The property owner shall, at the owner’s expense, install any culvert deemed
necessary under any driveway or any other access to the owner’s property, and
before installing a culvert, permission must first be obtained from the City.
In the event repairs are needed at any time with respect to culverts, it shall
be the responsibility of the property owner to make such repairs, and, in the
event the owner fails to do so, the City shall have the right to make the
repairs. If the property owner fails to reimburse the City for the cost of said
repairs, the cost shall be certified to the ’’’’County’ ’’Treasurer’’ and
specially assessed against the property as by law provided.
135.14   CURB CONSTRUCTION PERMITS.
Whenever any person desires to construct, reset, repair, or reconstruct any
curbing within the City, said person shall, before proceeding with such work,
obtain from the Clerk a permit to do so, and file written agreement with the
Building Inspector or Superintendent to comply with the specifications prepared
for such construction, resetting, repairing, or reconstruction of such curbing,
and perform such work under the direction and subject to the approval of the
street superintendent. All such permits shall be issued without charge and a
copy thereof, together with the written agreement above referred to, shall be
filed and preserved in the office of the Clerk. All such permits shall state
when the work is to be done.
CHAPTER 136
SIDEWALK REGULATIONS
136.01 Purpose                        136.10 Failure to Repair or Barricade
136.02 Definitions                    136.11 Interference with Sidewalk
                                      Improvements
136.03 Removal of Snow, Ice, and      136.12 Encroaching Steps
Accumulations
136.04 Responsibility for Maintenance 136.13 Openings and Enclosures
136.05 City May Order Repairs         136.14 Fires or Fuel on Sidewalks
136.06 Sidewalk Construction Ordered  136.15 Defacing
136.07 Permit Required and Building   136.16 Debris on Sidewalks
Permit Review
136.08 Sidewalk Standards             136.17 Merchandise Display
136.09 Barricades and Warning Lights  136.18 Sales Stands
 
136.01   PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to enhance safe passage by citizens on
sidewalks, to place the responsibility for the maintenance, repair,
replacement, or reconstruction of sidewalks upon the abutting property owner
and to minimize the liability of the City.
136.02   DEFINITIONS.
For use in this chapter the following terms are defined:
   1.   “Broom finish” means a sidewalk finish that is made by sweeping the
sidewalk when it is hardening.
   2.   “Business District” means the non-residential zoning areas within any
of the City business districts including General Business, Central Business,
Neighborhood Business District, Highway Service Business District, Heavy
General Business District, Light Manufacturing, or Industrial districts.
Business District shall also include any portion of a Planned Unit Development
area that includes non-residential, commercial business development.
   3.   “Defective sidewalk” means any public sidewalk exhibiting one or more
of the following characteristics:
      A.   Vertical separations equal to three-fourths (¾) inch or more.
      B.   Horizontal separations equal to one-half (½) inch or more.
      C.   Holes or depressions equal to three-fourths (¾) inch or more and at
least four (4) inches in diameter.
      D.   Spalling over fifty percent (50%) of a single square of the sidewalk
with one or more depressions equal to one-half (½) inch or more.
      E.   Spalling over less than fifty percent (50%) of a single square of
the sidewalk with one or more depressions equal to three-fourths (¾) inch or
more.
      F.   A single square of sidewalk cracked in such a manner that no part
thereof has a piece greater than one square foot.
      G.   A sidewalk with any part thereof missing to the full depth.
      H.   A change from the design or construction grade equal to or greater
than three-fourths (¾) inch per foot.
      I.   Vegetation overgrown in relief cuts or over sidewalk edges.
   4.   “Established grade” means that grade established by the City for the
particular area in which a sidewalk is to be constructed.
   5.   “One-course construction” means that the full thickness of the concrete
is placed at one time, using the same mixture throughout.
   6.   “Owner” means the person owning the fee title to property abutting any
sidewalk and includes any contract purchaser for purposes of notification
required herein. For all other purposes, “owner” includes the lessee, if any.
   7.   “Portland cement” means any type of cement except bituminous cement.
   8.   “Sidewalk” means all permanent public walks in business, residential or
suburban areas.
   9.   “Sidewalk improvements” means the construction, reconstruction, repair,
replacement, or removal, of a public sidewalk and/or the excavating, filling or
depositing of material in the public right-of-way in connection therewith.
   10.   “Wood float finish” means a sidewalk finish that is made by smoothing
the surface of the sidewalk with a wooden trowel.
(Ord. 765 – Aug. 25 Supp.)
136.03   REMOVAL OF SNOW, ICE, AND ACCUMULATIONS.
It is the responsibility of the abutting property owners to remove snow, ice,
and accumulations promptly from the entire sidewalk. If a property owner does
not remove snow, ice, or accumulations within a reasonable time, but in no case
no more than 24 hours after the snow or ice ceases to fall or accumulate, the
City may do so and assess the costs against the property owner for collection
in the same manner as a property tax. The Council may establish a schedule for
calculating costs by resolution. The abutting property owner may be liable for
damages caused by failure to abide by this duty.
(Ord. 765 – Aug. 25 Supp.)
136.04   RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE.
It is the responsibility of the abutting property owners to repair, replace or
reconstruct, or cause to be repaired, replaced or reconstructed, all broken or
defective sidewalks and to maintain in a safe and hazard-free condition any
sidewalk outside the lot and property lines and inside the curb lines or
traveled portion of the public street. However, this section shall not be
interpreted to require an abutting property owner to take any action with
respect to a public sidewalk or right-of way when said action is made necessary
by the excavation or other activity of the City or any other public utility or
authorized right of way user.
(Ord. 765 – Aug. 25 Supp.)
136.05   CITY MAY ORDER REPAIRS.
If the abutting property owner does not maintain sidewalks as required, the
Building Official may serve notice on such owner, by first-class or certified
mail, requiring the owner to repair, replace or reconstruct sidewalks within a
reasonable time and if such action is not completed within the time stated in
the notice, the Building Official may require the work to be done and assess
the costs against the abutting property for collection in the same manner as a
property tax.
(Ord. 765 – Aug. 25 Supp.)
136.06   SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION ORDERED.
Once a subdivision has five (5) or less lots left to be sold, the Developer
shall be responsible to construct remaining sidewalks within one (1) year. Once
an undeveloped residential lot is purchased the owner of the lot shall install
all required sidewalks within one (1) year of said purchase. The Council may
order the construction of permanent sidewalks upon any street or court in the
City and may specially assess the cost of such improvement to abutting property
owners in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 384 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.38)
(Ord. 667 - May 18 Supp.)
136.07   PERMIT REQUIRED AND BUILDING PERMIT REVIEW.
   1.   No person shall remove, reconstruct, or install a sidewalk unless such
person has obtained a permit from the City and has agreed in writing that said
removal, reconstruction, or installation will comply with all ordinances and
requirements of the City for such work.
   2.    Whenever a building permit application is required for new residential
structures or any scope of work on Business District property, an evaluation of
the site shall be conducted to determine whether a public sidewalk exists or is
required. If no sidewalk exists, the Building Official may require the
installation of an on-site sidewalk connecting the site to the existing or
required public sidewalk, in accordance with the provisions outlined in this
chapter.
(Ord. 765 – Aug. 25 Supp.)
136.08   SIDEWALK STANDARDS.
Sidewalks repaired, replaced, or constructed under the provisions of this
chapter shall be of the following construction and meet the following
standards:
   1.   Cement. Portland cement shall be the only cement used in the
construction, replacement and repair of sidewalks.
   2.   Construction. Sidewalks shall be of one-course construction.
   3.   Sidewalk Base. Concrete may be placed directly on compact and well-
drained soil. Where soil is not well drained, a three-inch sub-base of compact,
clean, coarse gravel or sand shall be laid. The adequacy of the soil drainage
is to be determined by the City.
   4.   Sidewalk Bed. The sidewalk bed shall be so graded that the constructed
sidewalk will be at established grade.
   5.   Length, Width and Depth. Length, width and depth requirements are as
follows:
      A.   Residential sidewalks shall be at least four (4) inches thick, and
each section shall be the same length as the width. Sidewalk widths shall be in
accordance with the following:
         (1)   Existing sidewalks and new sidewalks located in any residential
subdivision platted prior to January 1, 2017 shall be a minimum of four (4)
feet in width.
         (2)   New sidewalks in any residential subdivision platted after
January 1, 2017 shall be a minimum of five (5) feet in width.
      B.   Business District sidewalks shall extend to the curb. Each section
shall be (4) inches thick and a width of between a minimum of five (5) feet and
up to ten (10) feet as specified in an approved plan.
      C.   Driveway areas shall be not less than six (6) inches in thickness.
   6.   Location. Residential sidewalks shall be located with the inner edge
(edge nearest the abutting private property) one foot from the property line,
unless the City Administrator and the Building Official establish a different
distance due to special circumstances.
   7.   Grade. Curb tops shall be on level with the centerline of the street
which shall be the established grade.
   8.   Elevations. The street edge of a sidewalk shall be at an elevation even
with the curb at the curb or not less than one-half (½) inch above the curb for
each foot between the curb and the sidewalk.
   9.   Slope. All sidewalks shall slope one-quarter (¼) inch per foot toward
the curb.
   10.   Finish. All sidewalks shall be finished with a “broom” or “wood float”
finish.
   11.   Curb Ramps and Sloped Areas for Persons with Disabilities. If a
street, road, or highway is newly built or reconstructed, a curb ramp or sloped
area shall be constructed or installed at each intersection of the street,
road, or highway with a sidewalk or path. If a sidewalk or path is newly built
or reconstructed, a curb ramp or sloped area shall be constructed or installed
at each intersection of the sidewalk or path with a street, highway, or road.
